title: Zedekiah's Covenant Broken
shortSummary: Jeremiah 34 records God's message to King Zedekiah during the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem, foretelling the city's destruction and Zedekiah's capture. The chapter highlights the people's failure to uphold a covenant of liberty for Hebrew servants, resulting in God's judgment through exile and devastation.
timeline: c. 587 BC - Babylonian siege of Jerusalem under Nebuchadnezzar

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who delivers God's warnings and judgments to Judah and King Zedekiah.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who makes a covenant to free Hebrew servants but later breaks it, leading to divine judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadnezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon whose army besieges Jerusalem, fulfilling God's judgment.

definitions.definition: A solemn agreement or promise between God and His people, often involving commitments and blessings or curses.
Freedom granted to Hebrew servants to be released after a set period, as commanded in the Mosaic Law.
Servants or slaves, particularly Hebrew servants who were to be freed after six years of service.
An ancient covenant ritual involving cutting an animal in two and passing between the pieces to solemnize an oath.

outline.heading: Prophecy of Jerusalem’s Fall and Zedekiah’s Fate
outline.description: God reveals through Jeremiah that Nebuchadnezzar will capture and burn Jerusalem, and that King Zedekiah will be taken captive to Babylon but will die peacefully.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Message During the Siege
outline.description: Jeremiah delivers God’s words to Zedekiah amid the Babylonian military campaign against Jerusalem and remaining fortified cities.

outline.heading: The Covenant to Free Hebrew Servants
outline.description: Zedekiah makes a covenant to proclaim liberty to Hebrew servants, releasing them as commanded by God, but the people later break this covenant and re-enslave them.

outline.heading: God’s Reminder of the Original Covenant and Judgment
outline.description: God reminds the people of His covenant from Egypt commanding release of servants every seven years, condemns their disobedience, and declares judgment for breaking their oath.

outline.heading: Consequences for Zedekiah and Judah
outline.description: God pronounces that those who broke the covenant, including Zedekiah and his princes, will be delivered into enemy hands, Jerusalem will be captured again, burned, and Judah made desolate.

application: Obey God’s commands fully and avoid half-hearted obedience, especially in matters of justice and mercy.
Honor covenants and commitments as sacred before God, recognizing the seriousness of breaking them.
Trust God’s sovereignty even in times of judgment, knowing He fulfills His promises both of discipline and mercy.
Pray for faithfulness and courage to stand firm in obedience despite external pressures or threats.

keyVerses.text: This is the word that came unto Jeremiah from the LORD, after that the king Zedekiah had made a covenant with all the people which were at Jerusalem, to proclaim liberty unto them;
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the moment of covenant renewal and the call to obey God's law concerning liberty.

keyVerses.text: But ye turned and polluted my name, and caused every man his servant, and every man his handmaid, whom ye had set at liberty at their pleasure, to return, and brought them into subjection, to be unto you for servants and for handmaids.
keyVerses.significance: Shows the people's breach of covenant and the resulting defilement of God's name.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus saith the LORD; Ye have not hearkened unto me, in proclaiming liberty, every one to his brother, and every man to his neighbour: behold, I proclaim a liberty for you, saith the LORD, to the sword, to the pestilence, and to the famine; and I will make you to be removed into all the kingdoms of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: Declares the severe judgment for disobedience, contrasting the liberty they refused with the liberty of exile.

keyVerses.text: Behold, I will command, saith the LORD, and cause them to return to this city; and they shall fight against it, and take it, and burn it with fire: and I will make the cities of Judah a desolation without an inhabitant.
keyVerses.significance: Foretells the final destruction and desolation of Judah as a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness.
